<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 620, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of an oscillating metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 458, 120]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 829, 349]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 368, 532, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 144, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 593, 419]]<|/det|>
The student ensures that the metre rule is horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe how to check that the metre rule is horizontal. You may draw a diagram or draw on Fig. 1.1 if it helps to explain your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 617, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student moves the stands so that the vertical threads are at the marks on the metre rule shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 120, 860, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 294, 534, 313]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 326, 536, 344]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(d\) between the threads.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[576, 387, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 419, 144, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
He twists the metre rule a small amount, as shown in Fig. 1.3, and then lets it go so that it oscillates in a rotating motion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 876, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 580, 534, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 714, 630]]<|/det|>
He measures the time \(t\) for 5 complete oscillations of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[581, 636, 826, 656]]<|/det|>
<form>t = ....................................... $3.63$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 672, 693, 691]]<|/det|>
Suggest why it is useful to take a trial reading for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 734, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The student carries out the same procedure for \(d\) values of \(20.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\). His readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 119, 541, 135]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 144, 692, 312]]<|/det|>
\(d/\text {cm}\)\(t/\text {s}\)\(\frac {1}{T}/\frac {1}{s}\)
20.017.85
30.011.360.44
40.08.770.57
50.06.930.72
60.05.680.88
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 920, 380]]<|/det|> For distance \(d = 20.0 \text{cm}\), calculate and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{T}\) where \(T\) is the time for 1 oscillation of the metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 670, 397]]<|/det|> Use the value of time \(t\) from Table 1.1 and the equation \(\frac{1}{T} = \frac{5}{t}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 390, 920, 409]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 421, 144, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 415, 648, 444]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of distance \(d / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{T} /\frac{1}{s}\) (x-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 450, 744, 797]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 829, 143, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 829, 920, 863]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[574, 907, 920, 925]]<|/det|>
G = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 660, 91]]<|/det|>
Students investigate the cooling of hot water in two different cups.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 467, 121]]<|/det|>
They use the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Cup A is made from thin plastic. The top of cup A has an inside diameter of \(7\mathrm{cm}\). Cup B is made from expanded polystyrene. The top of cup B has an inside diameter of \(8\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 178, 834, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 526, 532, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 144, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 180, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 556, 784, 576]]<|/det|>
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 587, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = . ...............................................\)  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 618, 181, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 618, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** precaution that you would take to ensure that temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> A volume of \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water is poured into each cup and the initial temperature \(\theta\) is recorded in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> The temperature of the water in each cup is recorded every \(30 \text{s}\). The values are shown in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 150, 539, 166]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 175, 752, 400]]<|/det|>
cup Acup B
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)
087.588.0
3084.586.0
6082.084.5
9080.583.0
12079.082.0
15078.081.0
18077.080.5
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 455, 435]]<|/det|> Complete the headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 418, 920, 435]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 144, 467]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 920, 481]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating which cup, A or B, is the more effective in reducing the cooling rate of the hot water in this experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 544, 512]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 920, 638]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 666, 148, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 666, 180, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 666, 920, 698]]<|/det|> Calculate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\), the average cooling rate for cup A over the whole experiment. Use the readings for cup A from Table 2.1 and the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 702, 564, 732]]<|/det|> \[x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 743, 915, 776]]<|/det|> where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at time \(t = 0\) and at time \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 820, 920, 838]]<|/det|>
\(x_{\mathrm{A}} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 650, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates a resistor and a lamp connected in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 435, 104]]<|/det|>
She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 116, 796, 494]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 509, 532, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
The student moves the crocodile clip on the resistance wire so that the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) across the lamp is \(2.0 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 670, 604]]<|/det|>
She measures the current \(I\) for the lamp and resistor in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 617, 903, 635]]<|/det|>
She then connects the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across the resistor.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 647, 863, 819]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 836, 346, 853]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[656, 836, 728, 853]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 866, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
Read, and record in Table 3.1, the values of \(I\) and \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the meters in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 899, 920, 916]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student wishes to determine the resistance of the lamp \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\) when the potential difference across the lamp \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 0.0 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 895, 136]]<|/det|>
Describe how the experiment can be extended to do this with the help of a suitable graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
It is possible to use a variable resistor instead of a resistance wire to change the potential difference across the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 487, 337]]<|/det|>
Complete the circuit in Fig. 3.4 to show:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 171, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 522, 368]]<|/det|>
a variable resistor used for this purpose

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 168, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 843, 383]]<|/det|>
the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the resistor

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[328, 396, 685, 445]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 567, 688, 670]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 737, 534, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 737, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the average speed of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 557, 167]]<|/det|>
Average speed can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 173, 653, 202]]<|/det|>
\[\text{average speed} = \frac{\text{distance travelled}}{\text{time taken}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 398, 260]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 447, 290]]<|/det|>
balls of various sizes and materials

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 435, 305]]<|/det|>
a board which can act as a slope

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 480, 320]]<|/det|>
blocks to support one end of the board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 324, 352]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<label>•</label>
